questions.text:
A boy presented with a painful right knee swelling as seen in the image. He has a history of easy bruising and hematoma formation at injection sites. His lab investigation report is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this condition?
  • Platelet count - 4,00,000 /μL
  • Bleeding time - Normal
  • PT - Normal
  • aPTT - Prolonged
questions.solution:
The image showing knee joint swelling in a patient with bleeding tendency and prolonged aPTT indicates bleeding into the joint space, i.e. hemarthrosis due to hemophilia. The preferred treatment option among the ones given here is the administration of factor VIII concentrate.

Hemophilia is a coagulation disorder occurring due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII, leading to hemophilia A, or clotting factor IX, leading to hemophilia B. Hemophilia A and B are clinically indistinguishable and can be differentiated based on clotting factor assay. The disorder is X-linked recessive, meaning males are affected, and females are asymptomatic carriers.

Patients present with bleeding tendencies such as ecchymoses, epistaxis, haematuria, menorrhagia, hemarthrosis, prolonged bleeding after dental or minor surgical procedures, etc. Repeated hemarthrosis causes chronic synovitis and articular cartilage erosion, leading to hemophilic arthritis.

Laboratory findings in hemophilia:

  • Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - prolonged
  • Platelet count- normal
  • Bleeding time- normal
  • Prothrombin time- normal
  • The mixing of normal plasma with patient plasma results in the correction of the aPTT value.

Based on the percent activity of specific clotting factors, hemophilia is classified into:

Severity The activity of a specific clotting factor
Severe <1%
Moderate 1-5%
Mild >5%


Mild cases of hemophilia are treated by administration of desmopressin acetate. Moderate to severe cases need the replacement of deficient clotting factors. The monoclonal antibody emicizumab can bridge activated factor IX and factor X, thus restoring functional activated factor VIII activity in patients with hemophilia.

Please note that this patient could have either hemophilia A or B. The preferred treatment options for hemophilia are the administration of factor VIII and factor IX for hemophilia A and B, respectively. As factor IX is not given in the options, factor VIII is the best possible answer.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was brought to you with complaints of mucosal and joint bleeds. Laboratory investigation revealed the complete absence of  Von Willebrand factor (VWF) protein. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Complete quantitative deficiency of vWF protein is seen in Type 3 Von Willebrand disease.

von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Patients with VWD typically present with mucosal bleeding. VWD may be caused by quantitative or qualitative defects in VWF

  • Type 1 VWD: Partial quantitative deficiency of vWF 
  • Type 2 VWD: Qualitative deficiency of vWF
  • Type 3 VWD: Complete quantitative deficiency of vWF

Note: 

  • Type 1 VWD is the most common type, accounting for 60-80% of all VWD patients.
  • Most severe type is Type 3
  • Most common inheritance: Autosomal dominant

Characteristics of the subtypes of VWD are summarized below:

2N AR Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Autosomal hemophilia

questions.text: Romiplostim is a
questions.solution:
Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Eltrombopag is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the treatment of ITP and severe aplastic anemia.

Other options:

Option A- Epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa are recombinant human erythropoietin. They can be used in the treatment of anemias associated with surgery, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions. 

Option B- Filgrastim is a recombinant granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. It increases neutrophil production. It is used in the treatment of neutropenia. Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Option C- Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It increases thrombopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Sargramostim is a recombinant granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. It stimulates myelopoiesis. Important adverse effects are bone pain, malaise, flu-like symptoms, diarrhea, dyspnea, and rash.

questions.text: A peripheral smear showed small sized platelets. This is characteristic of ____________
questions.solution:
Small sized platelets on peripheral smear is a characteristic of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: There is a mutation in the gene encoding Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23. The X-linked disease is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

  • Platelets are small in size.
  • There is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and in the T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity.
  • Patients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigens is poor. They are prone to develop B-cell lymphomas.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female patient presents with petechiae and one episode of epistaxis. She gives a history of an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Her lab reports are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/μL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing petechiae and one episode of epistaxis following upper respiratory tract infection, and lab reports showing a platelet count of 12,000/μL are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Since this patient has had only one episode of epistaxis and her hemoglobin is normal, the most appropriate management for this patient would be prednisolone.

In patients without significant bleeding and without severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 5000 cells/μL), the initial treatment is with glucocorticoids such as prednisolone or dexamethasone.

If the patient has severe bleeding or severe thrombocytopenia, IVIg and glucocorticoids are used in conjunction. Anti-D is used as an alternative to IVIg, but is not preferred because of the risk of severe hemolytic reactions. Platelet transfusions (option B) are reserved for patients in whom there is a need to immediately raise the platelet counts. 

The decision to start treatment in a patient who is incidentally diagnosed and doesn't have any bleeding manifestations is based on the platelet count. Treatment is usually started for these patients if the platelet count is < 30,000 cells/μL.

Splenectomy (option C) has been used previously for patients who relapse after glucocorticoid therapy, but is now a reserved treatment option. In most adult patients, ITP resolves spontaneously, and so it is reasonable to observe the patient with intermittent treatment with IVIg before surgery is considered.

Other drugs which are used in the treatment of ITP include anti-CD20 antibody rituximab, and thrombopoietin (TPO) receptor agonists such as romiplostim and eltrombopag.

questions.text:
A girl presented to the casualty with anuria for 2 days and a recent history of fever and bloody diarrhea 5 days back. An examination reveals petechiae on the trunk and jaundice of the skin, but no neurological deficit. Schistocytes are seen on a peripheral smear and other lab findings are shown below. Besides supportive care, what is the best step in management?
  • Hemoglobin: 8.6 g/dL
  • Leukocyte count: 12,000/mm³
  • Platelet count: 32,000/mm³
  • Serum Blood urea nitrogen:48 mg/dL
  • Creatinine: 2.7 mg/dL
  • S. Potassium 6.2
  • ABG: pH=7.06
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of this child, along with lab investigations suggests a diagnosis of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) causing AKI resulting in acidosis and hyperkalemia. Thus the patient should be managed with hemodialysis.

Up to half of the patients with HUS may require dialysis support during the acute phase of the disease. The patient’s symptoms (anuria) and lab findings (acidosis, hyperkalemia) align with the indications for dialysis in AKI. Indications include:

  1. Anuria/oliguria
  2. Severe metabolic acidosis
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Uremic symptoms, such as pericarditis or encephalopathy
  5. Fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics

HUS is a condition characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. It commonly affects children up to 5 years of age. The disease is often linked to a preceding gastrointestinal infection caused by Shiga toxin-producing strains like E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae.

There is widespread injury to small vessel endothelium, leading to thrombotic microangiopathy. The formation of these microthrombi causes a decrease in platelet count. There is associated destruction of RBCs causing hemolytic anemia. Renal vascular occlusion by microthrombi results in acute kidney injury.

Investigations will show a hemolytic blood picture with reticulocytosis and schistocytes on a peripheral smear. There will be reduced platelets and deranged renal function tests. Liver function tests will reveal an elevated indirect bilirubin.

Other options

Option A: Platelet transfusions are generally not recommended in HUS unless there is active bleeding because ongoing microangiopathic processes rapidly consume platelets and transfusions may exacerbate the condition.

Option B The patient's hemoglobin is 8.6 g/dL, which is mildly low. However, RBC transfusion is generally reserved for more severe anemia with Hb<7g/dL.

Option D. Antibiotics are ineffective in treating HUS and may worsen the hemolysis and stimulate the release of Shiga toxin.

questions.text: Patients with protein C deficiency are at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Spontaneous bleeding is not seen in protein C deficiency. It is characterised by an increased tendency for thrombus formation.

Protein C deficiency is a rare genetic disorder. It predisposes to the following thrombotic complications:

  • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT):
    • Adults with a mild form of the disease at higher risk of developing venous thromboembolism.
  • Purpura fulminans:
    • Severe form of DIC
    • Thrombosis of extensive areas of the skin
    • Affects predominantly young children following viral or bacterial infection. 
  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis:
    • Rare complication seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or S.
    • Thrombosis of the skin leads to well-demarcated erythematous lesions with central necrosis on the thighs, buttocks, breasts, or toes(shown below).

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presented with a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds. There was no history of fever. The platelet count was low and the peripheral smear showed platelets, as marked by the arrows. Platelet function studies show an absence of aggregation to ristocetin but a normal response to adenosine diphosphate (ADP), epinephrine, and collagen. What is the likely diagnosis?

aPTT: Normal
Bleeding time: prolonged
Serum creatinine and urea within normal limits
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Points that favor the diagnosis:

  • History of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds
  • Low platelet count and giant platelets
  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Absent aggregation to ristocetin in platelet function studies 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. 

They mostly present with easy bruising, nose bleeds, mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, and occasionally gastrointestinal bleeding.

Laboratory features:

  • Low platelet count
  • Large platelets on smear
  • Platelet aggregation will not occur in response to ristocetin but have normal aggregation with  ADP, collagen, or epinephrine
  • Platelet membrane glycoprotein abnormality is seen on flow cytometry.

Supportive treatment is only needed. Antiplatelet medications like aspirin should be avoided. Anti-fibrinolytic can be used in mucosal bleeding.

The below image shows giant platelets in peripheral blood smear in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive platelet disorder that results from a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex.

Patients mainly present with petechiae, ecchymosis, excessive bleeding after dental extraction, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and epistaxis. 

Laboratory features:

  • Normal platelet count
  • Bleeding time- prolonged
  • Normal platelet morphology on peripheral smear
  • Platelet aggregation responses to ADP, collagen, or epinephrine are low but have normal aggregation with ristocetin
  • Flow cytometry and monoclonal antibodies confirm the diagnosis

Option B-  Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is due to the deficiency of ADAMTS13, which is the negative regulator of von Willebrand factor (vWF). They are mostly seen in adults less than 40 years of age.

They are classically manifested by a pentad of:

  • Fever
  • Neurological abnormalities
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure

Option C- von Willebrand disease is a common inherited disorder caused by deficiency or dysfunction of the vWF. Patients will have thrombocytopenia with mild to moderate mucocutaneous hemorrhage.

Laboratory features:

  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Slightly enlarged platelets
  • Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor
  • Low levels of ristocetin cofactor
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)and bleeding time

questions.text:
Match the Tests used to assess the Coagulation pathway with their use.

 

Test Use

1. Prothrombin Time (PT)		 a. Evaluates the ability of platelets to form a hemostatic plug
2. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) b. Evaluates the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways
3. Thrombin time (TT) c. Evaluates the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways.
4. Bleeding time (BT) d. Evaluate the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin
questions.solution:
The correctly matched order of the tests used to assess the Coagulation pathway with their use is  1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a (Option A)

Test Use
1. Prothrombin Time (PT) b. Evaluates the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways.
2. Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) c. Evaluates the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways.
3. Thrombin time (TT)
d. Evaluate the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin.
4. Bleeding time (BT)
a. Evaluate the ability of platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 

1) Prothrombin time is the time taken for citrated plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It evaluates the extrinsic pathway and common pathways, i.e., factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen. Normal PT is 11 to 16 seconds. Causes of prolonged PT include Liver diseases, Vitamin K deficiency, Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), Factor VII, X, V, or prothrombin deficiency.

2) Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) is the time taken for citrated plasma to clot in the presence of a surface activator (kaolin), phospholipid, and calcium. It evaluates intrinsic and common pathways, i.e., factors VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, V, II, and fibrinogen. Normal APTT is 30 to 40 seconds. APTT is prolonged in Hemophilias that involve deficiencies of factor VIII, IX or XI, DIC, Liver diseases, etc.

3) Bleeding Time (BT) is used as a screening test for disorders of platelet-vessel wall interactions. It measures the time required for bleeding to stop after a standardized superficial cut of the skin capillary bed. It assesses platelet number and function. The normal BT is 2-8 minutes. Prolonged bleeding time is found in thrombocytopenia and Von Willebrand disease.

4) Thrombin Time (TT) assesses the effectiveness of the final step of coagulation in which fibrinogen is converted to fibrin. Thrombin is added to the plasma along with calcium, and clotting time is determined. The normal value of TT is 15 to 19 seconds. Prolonged TT is seen in conditions with decreased fibrinogen concentration, like DIC and afibrinogenemia.

5) Clotting time measures the time taken for the fresh blood to clot. Normal: 3–6 minutes. It is one of the oldest tests and is not sensitive as it fails to detect mild/ moderate coagulant defects. Hence, it is not preferred as a screening test. It is prolonged in severe deficiency of factor VIII, IX, or fibrinogen (afibrinogenemia) and in heparin therapy

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents with jaundice, confusion, and aphasia. Peripheral smear shows the presence of schistocytes. Coagulation studies were found to be normal but platelet count is decreased. Serum haptoglobin levels are low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits to form at various sites in the circulation. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations. On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

MAHA is an example of intravascular hemolysis. It causes an increase in free hemoglobin in the blood, which is taken up by haptoglobin. This reduces free haptoglobin in the blood. Moreover, the activation of the coagulation cascade is not of primary importance in TTP and HUS, and hence the coagulation studies are usually normal. The mainstay of treatment of TTP is therapeutic plasma exchange.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options:

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have abnormally large platelets (megathrobocytes) in the peripheral smear, which is a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis. Coagulation studies are normal. 

Option B: Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, and oozing from venipuncture sites. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smears. Deranged clotting parameters are seen and fibrin degradation products such as D-dimers are elevated.

Option C: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common.

questions.text:
A patient undergoing a pre-op evaluation has an isolated prolonged aPTT. Further investigations show deficient levels of factor XII but he has no history of spontaneous bleeding. Which of the following is the best way to manage this patient?

aPTT: activated partial thromboplastin time

choices.text: Give Factor XII concentrate before surgery
Proceed with surgery without any treatment
Transfuse fresh frozen plasma before surgery

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient is to proceed with surgery without additional treatment.

Factor XII deficiency leads to a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) in vitro, but it does not increase the risk of bleeding in vivo. This discrepancy is due to the role of factor XII in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, which does not significantly impact hemostasis in vivo. Patients with Factor XII deficiency typically do not exhibit hemorrhagic symptoms and thus will have normal hemostasis during surgical procedures.

questions.text:
A young woman in the casualty with right leg pain, swelling, and erythema is diagnosed with a DVT. She had a pulmonary embolism six months ago and was treated with warfarin, which was recently stopped. Coagulation assays show insensitivity to activated protein C. What is the likely finding upon further evaluation?

DVT: Deep Vein Thrombosis
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation of DVT and history of pulmonary embolism, along with insensitivity to activated protein C, strongly suggests a Factor V Leiden mutation.

The mutation occurs in the Factor V gene and leads to the production of a Factor V protein that is resistant to inactivation by activated protein C (APC). Normally, APC degrades Factor V to prevent excessive clotting, but in individuals with Factor V Leiden, this process is impaired, leading to a higher risk of forming abnormal blood clots.

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited thrombophilia, which follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Heterozygous carriers have a 3 to 8 times increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), while homozygous individuals have a significantly higher risk, approximately 50 to 100 times greater.

Patients with Factor V Leiden are at increased risk for conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). The risk is further elevated in situations such as pregnancy, oral contraceptive use, and prolonged immobilization.

The diagnosis is typically confirmed through genetic testing for the Factor V Leiden mutation. Coagulation assays showing APC resistance are also indicative of this condition.

Management of patients with Factor V Leiden involves anticoagulation therapy during episodes of thrombosis. Long-term anticoagulation may be considered in patients with recurrent thrombotic events or significant risk factors. Preventive measures are crucial for high-risk situations to reduce the likelihood of thromboembolic events.

Other options:

Option A: While elevated homocysteine can increase the risk of thrombosis, it does not cause APC resistance.

Option C: The prothrombin gene mutation (G20210A) increases prothrombin levels, leading to a higher risk of clotting, but it does not involve APC resistance.

Option D: This condition leads to reduced inhibition of thrombin and other clotting factors, increasing clotting risk, but it is not associated with APC resistance.

questions.text: A woman presents with episodic nose and gum bleeding over the past two weeks. She is not on any medications. Examination reveals a hemoglobin level of 13.1 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 6600/mm³, a platelet count of 28,000/mm³, and a normal coagulation profile. A peripheral smear shows normal-sized platelets with no abnormal cells. Which diagnostic test is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with isolated thrombocytopenia suggests immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Hepatitis C serology is essential to rule out secondary causes in suspected ITP patients thus HCV serology is indicated.

In patients suspected of having  Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP), secondary causes such as infections should be ruled out. Hepatitis C and HIV serology should be obtained in adults with suspected primary immune thrombocytopenia, as treating these infections is likely to improve thrombocytopenia.

Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder characterized by immune-mediated destruction of platelets and inhibition of platelet release from megakaryocytes. It can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to underlying conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV, and Hepatitis C.

Patients usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding, including petechiae, and purpura, often following minor trauma. Severe bleeding, such as gastrointestinal or intracranial hemorrhage, is rare.

The diagnosis of ITP is primarily clinical, supported by laboratory findings of isolated thrombocytopenia with a normal coagulation profile and peripheral smear. 

Initial Treatment is with glucocorticoids to reduce immune-mediated platelet destruction. For severe thrombocytopenia or bleeding, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) and anti-D immunoglobulin can be used. For patients who relapse or do not respond to glucocorticoids, splenectomy is considered. Thrombopoietin receptor agonists like Eltrombpag and immunosuppressive agents like rituximab are other options.

Other options

Option A: ADAMTS 13 testing is indicated in patients with suspected thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which typically presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia characterized by low hemoglobin and schistocytes on a peripheral smear.

Option C: Bone marrow biopsy is not routinely required for diagnosing ITP unless there are atypical findings on peripheral smear or a lack of response to treatment. It is generally reserved for cases where myelodysplastic syndrome or leukemia is suspected.

Option D:  Antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF-4) are seen in Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) which may occur 5-10 days after initiation of Heparin. This patient is not taking Heparin.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

  1. PT
  2. D-Dimer

questions.solution:
The ISTH criteria include platelet count, D-dimer, fibrinogen, and prothrombin time, therefore option C is correct.

The ISTH has created a scoring system to help diagnose overt DIC. This system evaluates platelet count, D-dimer levels, prothrombin time (PT), and fibrinogen levels, assigning points based on the severity of each parameter. The total score derived from these points assists in the diagnosis of DIC:

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acquired syndrome characterized by the widespread activation of blood clotting factors within blood vessels,  throughout the body. This can result in multiple organ dysfunction and severe bleeding due to the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors. The primary mechanism of DIC involves the uncontrolled generation of thrombin through pathways leading to sustained coagulation activation, the formation of fibrin, and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets.

Infections are the most frequent cause of DIC.

The following lab findings are seen in DIC: 

  1. Decreased platelet count
  2. Prolonged PT/TT
  3. Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
  4. Decreased fibrinogen
  5. Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers)
  6. Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells)

The treatment involves platelet transfusion when platelet counts are below 10,000-20,000/μL. Replacement of fibrinogen and coagulation factors is with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) along with cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate.

In cases of low-grade DIC associated with solid tumors or acute promyelocytic leukemia low doses of continuous-infusion heparin have been effective.

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

questions.text: Two patients, A and B, present with frequent nosebleeds. On further investigations, it is revealed that they have a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX and glycoprotein IIb–IIIa respectively. Which of the following lab tests will you order to confirm their diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ristocetin cofactor assay can be used to differentiate patient A who has Bernard–Soulier syndrome(deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor) from patient B who has Glanzmann's thrombasthenia(deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor).

This is because the ristocetin cofactor assay tests the integrity of the Gp Ib binding to the Von Willebrand factor. This will be normal in patients with Glanzmann's. So, this test can be used to differentiate Bernard–Soulier syndrome (abnormal ristocetin aggregation) from Glanzmann's thrombasthenia (normal ristocetin aggregation) .

Bernard–Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia are caused due to deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor and deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor respectively. In both these conditions, platelet count and PT/PTT is normal, with only an increase in bleeding time. 

Specific platelet aggregation tests with collagen, ADP, etc. will fail to bring about platelet aggregation in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia. Whereas, in Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation tests are normal.

Other options:

Option B: Platelet count is not specific enough to diagnose deficiencies of the mentioned glycoproteins.

Options C: Bleeding time assesses overall platelet function but does not directly diagnose the specific glycoprotein deficiencies.

Options D: PT/PTT are coagulation tests and can help identify clotting disorders but are not specific for glycoprotein deficiencies.

questions.text: A grandmother has noticed that her granddaughter's umbilical stump hasn't fallen off even after 4 weeks. On examination, the pediatrician notices mild bruising. Which of the following clotting factor deficiencies should he suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of the umbilical stump beyond 4 weeks is a characteristic finding seen in factor XIII deficiency. However, these findings can also be seen in septicemia or local infections.

Factor XIII is responsible for the crosslinking of fibrin to stabilize the fibrin clot, symptoms of delayed hemorrhage are secondary to the instability of the clot. Typically, patients have trauma one day and then have a bruise or hematoma the next day.

Results of the usual screening tests for hemostasis are normal in patients with factor XIII deficiency. Screening tests for factor XIII deficiency are based on the observation that there is increased solubility of the clot because of the failure of cross-linking.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn?
questions.solution:
The age of onset of classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is 2-7 days. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes include:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

Classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn occurs early in the newborn period, typically between day 2 and 7 of life, and most often in exclusively breastfeeding infants who did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis at birth.

Early-onset vitamin K deficiency bleeding (after birth but in first 24 hr) occurs if the mother has been treated chronically with certain drugs that interfere with vitamin K absorption or function. (Option C)

Late-onset vitamin K deficiency bleeding (1-6 months of life) is usually associated with conditions that feature malabsorption of the fat-soluble vitamin K, such as cystic fibrosis, neonatal hepatitis, or biliary atresia. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.text: A child is brought with hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma. On testing, you find an isolated prolongation of prothrombin time. Which of the following clotting factors is likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis following a trivial trauma is suggestive of a bleeding disorder and that associated with an isolated prolonged prothrombin time shows that clotting factor VII is likely to be deficient in this patient.  

Prothrombin time (PT) assesses the extrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time (in seconds) needed for plasma to clot after the addition of an exogenous source of tissue thromboplastin and calcium ions. A prolonged PT can occur due to deficiencies/dysfunction of factors V, VII, X, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) assesses the intrinsic pathway and common coagulation pathways. It measures the time needed for plasma to clot after the addition of kaolin (to activate XII), cephalin (substitutes platelet phospholipids), and calcium ions. aPTT is prolonged due to dysfunction of V, VIII, IX, X, XI, XII, prothrombin, and fibrinogen.  

Thus this shows that factor VII deficiency is associated with isolated prolongation of PT.

Clotting factor VII deficiency, otherwise known as Alexander's disease, is usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It can present with recurrent episodes of bleeding into joints, muscles, and closed spaces that start spontaneously or following an injury. Diagnosis can be made by lab results of PT and aPTT and confirmed with factor VII assay. Patients are treated with recombinant factor VIIa.  

Other options:

Option B & C: Factor VIII and IX deficiency, otherwise known as hemophilia A & B respectively, are associated with isolated prolonged aPTT.

Option D: Factor II deficiency is associated with prolongation of both PT and aPTT.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with generalised weakness and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Blood investigations reveal Hb of 5 g/dL, platelet count of 15,000/μL, and WBC count of 3000/μL. What findings are expected to be seen in a bone marrow biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.
Numerous needle-like azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes.
Erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of generalised weakness, recurrent epistaxis, impalpable spleen and blood investigations showing pancytopenia, are suggestive of Aplastic anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). The patient will have

  • Decreased red blood cells leading to anemia
  • Decreased white blood cells leading to recurrent infections
  • Decreased platelets leading to petechiae and ecchymoses.

Many other leukemias and lymphomas may have a similar presentation. However, splenomegaly is characteristically absent in these patients. 

The bone marrow is markedly hypocellular. It is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells. Marrow aspirates yield a dry tap having only fat cells, fibrous stroma, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Aplasia is best appreciated in marrow biopsies. 

The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow.

Treatment includes:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients.
  • Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors.
  • Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as an add-on therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Bone marrow examination showing macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance is seen in Gaucher disease, due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency. The patients present with haematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and pathological fractures. 

Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia is most commonly seen in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes (black arrow) along with a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow).

Option D: Bone marrow examination showing erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts is seen in sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia are a group of disorders characterized by the presence of nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain prussian blue positive (sideroblasts). They can be also seen in myelodysplastic syndrome and lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient comes to the medical outpatient department with increased frequency and burning micturition. He has a mechanical heart valve and is undergoing warfarin therapy for his transient ischaemic attacks. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity and he is started on antibiotics. The next day he comes with complaints of excessive bleeding after a trivial injury. Which of the following antibiotics was most probably prescribed?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing a man with a mechanical valve who is undergoing warfarin therapy presenting with excessive bleeding is most likely due to the administration of the antibiotic cotrimoxazole.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that inhibit the CYP2C9 enzyme, like cotrimoxazole, reduce the metabolism of warfarin and thus, enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin and increase the risk of bleeding.

Warfarin interactions:

Interactions with warfarin can be caused due to alteration in the absorption and metabolism of the drug, the circulating levels of clotting factors, and the state of epithelial surface.

Reduced efficacy:

  • Decreased absorption - COnjugation with cholestyramine
  • Increased clearance - CYP2C9 activation by drugs (barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin)
  • Reduced circulating volume - Nephrotic syndrome
  • Resistance - High Vitamin K consumption, High circulating clotting factor levels in pregnancy

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole
    • Fluoxetine
    • Sulfinpyrazone
    • Zafirlukast

Other options:

Options A and D - Tetracycline and Cephalexin (belonging to cephalosporins) are almost completely metabolized and excreted by the kidneys and hence do not interact with Warfarin.

Option C - Clindamycin is metabolized to N-demethylclindamycin and clindamycin sulfoxide, which are then excreted in the urine and bile. It does not cause CYP2C9 inhibition.
